instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
hello,
can someone help me with this board please im new in this and i cant figure out what is wrong with this board,
i have already tried another DC in board, i have only a dimmed green light on the charger almost invisible

i have done some measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.58V

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.41V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL> = 8.59V

<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_ISOL_R</SIGNAL> = 16.64V

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.38V

J7000 = pin 1 and 2= 16.66V

j7000 = pin 3 =0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
Welcome to the forum!

Did you try known good LIO flex too?
Inspect J9500 solders, especially pins 19/21.

Board must turn on without LIO flex connected; no Magsafe light, of course.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
hello, 
no i did not try an new flex cable because i dont have one, J9500 pins look perfect  i see nowhere corrosion or something,
what else can it be? does the <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_ISOL_R</SIGNAL> have to be around 18v? because i have 16.6V can this be the issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
DCIN depends of charger type used.

We can help better if you reply to the questions...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message: im using 85W charger, and i do have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> i have measured 3.32V on <CAPACITOR>C8130</CAPACITOR> and on <CAPACITOR>C8309</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>???
Pay atention when you read and earn time; should be your interest...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message: I cant find the <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>  thats why i thought that you mean maybe sys? But i didnt find it either, can you tel me where it is located on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message: Sorry i did find it now and its also 3.32V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads) and check for drop pulse at same time on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If yes, check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
hello, sorry for the late reply. these are the measurements.

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = measured on <RESISTOR>R8133</RESISTOR> 3.19V

<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>= <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR> 3.02V

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = <RESISTOR>R1451</RESISTOR> 3.41V

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = <TRANSISTOR>Q3000</TRANSISTOR> 3.31V

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, 3.40V when pressed  drops to0.35V

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4V and when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> triggered the voltage drops to 0.35V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> =  0.4V and when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> triggered the voltage stays the same 

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = is always 0V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = is always 0V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = is always 0V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = is always 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
More likely the problem is on PCH side, if you don't get reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> at least.
Check first all RTC signals, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>.
Also see what happens when <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> is removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.31V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.30V 
 <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>  = 2.95V
 <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.31V

i have removed the <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> but what for changes should i be looking for?
i will have to order new <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> because its damaged

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
Sorry, I mixed posts and schematics.
Remove <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> and check if you get voltage on big coils.
No need to solder <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> yet, for test.
If you get at leat pulsing at 5V and RAM coils, then need to solder <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message: i did remove the <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> but there was no difference, i did see some corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> but i have cleaned it all can the issue be there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message: Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>, is not really needed; redundant protection...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:
i have removed it but still the same..i think i will pass on this board and use it just for parts because i have one more board that is working but only the backlight is not working. when i turn on the macbook the backlight voltage is slowly dropping from 19V to 8.49V..
and i have already replaced the backlight driver.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> air 13 2015 NO POWER
threads.message:

Different problem must be treated separately.
